section.title: INTRODUCTION
section.para: Streamflow is made up of two main conceptual components which are categorised using the catchment response following a rainfall event. Water that enters a stream rapidly is termed “quickflow” or “direct runoff” and is sourced from short-term storages within the catchment; these short-term storages form the catchment storage through which the runoff flows while travelling to the catchment outlet. Water that takes longer to reach a river is termed “baseflow” and is sourced primarily from depletion of long-term storages within the catchment; typically, water in these long-term storages is held as soil moisture or as groundwater. At any instance in time, different locations will have varying magnitudes of baseflow contribution to the streamflow due to differing regional hydrogeological conditions and antecedent conditions.
A baseflow hydrograph as described by Nathan and McMahon (1990) and Brodie and Hostetler (2005) is considered to have the following features:

listitem.para: The flow before the start of a flood event generally is assumed to consist entirely of baseflow. In other words, during the initial periods of a runoff event, the flow is considered to consist entirely of baseflow.

The rapid rise of the streamflow during a rainfall event increases the volume of water held as bank storage. This water returns to the main streamflow after a delay and creates a baseflow peak after the main flood peak.
The recession of the baseflow peak continues after the recession of the streamflow peak.
The baseflow recession generally follows an exponential decay function.
The baseflow hydrograph re-joins the total hydrograph as the direct runoff ceases.

section.para: As discussed earlier in Book 1 of Australian Rainfall and Runoff and by Ball et al. (2011), a common approach to generation of the data necessary for prediction of design flood characteristics is the use of catchment modelling systems. These catchment modelling systems focus on the simulation of those processes influencing “direct runoff” and the baseflow component of streamflow either is ignored or is incorporated after the direct runoff has been estimated. It is the later approach that is the focus herein, namely the estimation of the baseflow hydrograph for addition to the direct runoff hydrograph after the direct runoff hydrograph has been predicted.

section.title: BASEFLOW CHARACTERISTICS
section.para: For design flood estimation in Australia, baseflow has typically been considered to be a relatively minor contributor, but can potentially be significant in more frequent events. This is particularly the case where the catchment geology consists of high yielding aquifers with high levels of baseflow.

In the context of design flood estimation, a surface runoff hydrograph will typically be generated that excludes baseflow. It is necessary to estimate the baseflow contribution in order to completely represent the total event peak and volume, and to generate a total streamflow hydrograph. This concept is represented in Figure 1. This document provides a technique for quantifying baseflow contribution to design flood estimates.
To support this, it is relevant to identify a number of features of an event hydrograph, shown in Figure 1:

listitem.para: Surface runoff peak: the maximum flow associated with the surface runoff event.
Time to the surface runoff peak: measured from the start of the event to the surface runoff peak.
Volume of surface runoff for the event: event volume, represented by the area under the hydrograph.

section.para: Information on the surface runoff characteristics will generally be available directly from the surface runoff hydrograph generated by practitioners for the design flood event.
Key baseflow features are also presented for the same event in Figure 1:

listitem.para: Baseflow peak: maximum baseflow associated with the event.
Time to the baseflow peak: measured from the start of the event to the baseflow peak.
Baseflow under the surface runoff peak: baseflow that occurs at the time of the surface runoff peak.

section.para: The total streamflow hydrograph can be estimated by combining the surface runoff and baseflow components. This concept is also depicted in Figure 1.

section.title: SELECTION OF APPROACH
section.para: The approach to quantifying baseflow is dependent upon the catchment characteristics, data availability and baseflow characteristics of the catchment. Figure 2 provides a decision pathway to determine the most suitable approach to estimate baseflow contribution to design flood events, based on site specific criteria. Further details of the decision pathway and most appropriate approach are outlined below.

figure.title: Decision tree for method to estimate baseflow contribution to design flood

section.title: Preliminary assessment of baseflow
section.para: A preliminary assessment should be undertaken to consider whether baseflow is likely to be a significant component of the design flood hydrograph. A detailed analysis task is not suggested at this point. Instead, this assessment is intended to be a coarse screening test to help determine the most appropriate approach to estimate baseflow for the catchment of interest based on local baseflow characteristics. A number of tools are available to support this assessment:

listitem.para: Figure 3 is provided to readily identify the relative magnitude of baseflow compared to surface runoff for catchments across Australia. Practitioners can identify their catchment of interest within this data set and note the value of the Baseflow Peak Factor. This map shows catchments to match with the screening criteria identified below, while Figure 5 and Figure 6 (and associated spatial data) provide a more detailed estimate of baseflow.

If available, streamflow data for the catchment should be reviewed. The magnitude of low flows relative to peaks can be used to determine whether baseflow is likely to be an important component of the flood hydrograph.

section.para: Where baseflow is a small component compared to the surface runoff, the design flood peak can simply be adjusted by up to 5% to make an allowance for baseflow. This approach is considered relevant for catchments where baseflow is estimated to represent less than approximately 5% of the surface runoff for a flood event. Catchments with a Baseflow Peak Factor less than 0.05 are considered suitable for this approach. This reflects approximately 30% of the catchments mapped in Figure 3.

It is suggested that catchments that have a baseflow contribution greater than approximately 5% of the surface runoff should explicitly incorporate the baseflow component into the design flood using a more rigorous approach.

Where baseflow is a very large component of the event (a contribution of more than 30% is suggested, reflected by a Baseflow Peak Factor greater than 0.3), it is considered important that baseflow is considered based on site-specific analyses using techniques that are suited to the nature and availability of local data (e.g. see Brodie and Hostetler, 2005; Chapman and Maxwell, 1996; Nathan and McMahon, 1990). Catchments located in tropical north Australia, south-west Western Australia and the south east coastline of South Australia may fall into this category.

Where baseflow is between approximately 5% and 30% of the surface runoff (Baseflow Peak Factor between 0.05 and 0.3), the approach outlined below is recommended. This relates to approximately 75% of the catchments mapped in Figure 3.

section.title: Suitability of stream flow data
section.para: Where possible, recorded streamflow data should be used directly to quantify baseflow. However, ideally more than 10 years of continuous streamflow data would be required to undertake detailed site-specific analyses. Appropriate data quality checks should be undertaken prior to ascertaining the period of record available for analysis. Preferably, the streamflow data should extend over a period of record that enables the identification of an event of similar magnitude to the design flood of interest.
In addition, there are various activities that can affect streamflows and interfere with the flow characteristics usually associated with baseflow. These activities include:

listitem.para: Flow regulation from upstream reservoirs – reservoirs that release outflows that are different to inflows will produce a low flow response that can be misinterpreted as baseflow at downstream flow gauges.
Catchment farm dams: high concentrations of catchment farm dams could also influence baseflow but only where the dams are located on-stream or where they interact with groundwater.

Major diversions – diversions for consumptive use such as irrigation channels, urban diversions, etc. These diversions can decrease low flows and hence appear to reduce estimates of baseflow. Allowances can be made for those diversions where they are metered.
Urbanisation – In urban areas, activities such as excess garden or sports field watering can increase low flows during summer that appear similar to baseflow in streamflow data.
Return flows – Water can be returned to rivers from sewage treatment plants or from industry. This will increase low flows and appear similar to baseflow.

section.para: Where present, these activities will influence the observed flow characteristics making it difficult to identify and quantify baseflow. While it is possible to estimate baseflow in these locations using the regional approach, the baseflow estimate will reflect the unregulated baseflow conditions.

section.title: QUANTIFYING BASEFLOW CONTRIBUTION TO DESIGN FLOOD ESTIMATES
Estimating baseflow using streamflow data
section.para: As outlined in Section 3.2, available streamflow criteria should meet a number of conditions to be considered suitable for application to assess baseflow. If streamflow data does not meet these criteria, this approach is not relevant and practitioners are directed to the regional approach outlined in Section 4.2.
To estimate baseflow directly from available streamflow data, the following steps should be followed:

listitem.para: Review the streamflow data and eliminate any poor quality data as determined using the quality codes for each time step.

Determine the resulting period of record available for analysis. If less than 10 years of data is available, the regional approach in Section 4.2 is more appropriate for application. If more than 10 years of data is available, the following steps can be applied.

Ideally, in order to identify flood events of similar magnitude to the design flood of interest, the period of available streamflow data should be greater than the Average Recurrence Interval ARI1
1Note that the exceedance probability has been expressed as an average recurrence interval as the approach caters down to 2-per-year. For ARI >1 the values should be interpreted as annual exceedance probabilities rather than periods between exceedances. of interest.

Undertake an analysis of the available streamflow data to identify flood events in the data record. It is recommended that as a minimum, the 10 year ARI event should be identified. If the streamflow data record is suitable, identify events of similar magnitude to the design flood of interest.

Estimate the baseflow for the flood events identified in the step above. Literature such as Nathan and McMahon (1990), Chapman & Maxwell, 1996 and Brodie and Hostetler (2005) provide guidance on key features of the baseflow hydrograph. Again, the 10 year event should be estimated as a minimum. If the streamflow data is suitable, the baseflow should be estimated for events of similar magnitude to the design flood of interest. Baseflow should be estimated graphically from the streamflow hydrograph.

If the above step has been applied to events of similar magnitude to the design flood of interest, the estimated baseflow magnitude and volume can be used directly with the design flood surface runoff hydrograph to generate the total streamflow estimate. Refer to Section 4.3 for a description of how to generate the total streamflow hydrograph. In this case, the key baseflow features, including the time series of the baseflow, should be taken from the baseflow estimated in the above step.

If the above step has been applied only to the 10 year event, it is necessary to scale the baseflow to reflect the ARI of interest. The method outlined in Section 4.2 should be applied, with the key baseflow characteristics calculated based on the outcomes from the step above rather than sourced from the national catchment maps.
The remaining steps in Section 4.3 should be implemented based on the baseflow characteristics identified in the streamflow data for the 10 year ARI event.

section.title: Estimating baseflow in the absence of streamflow data
section.para: A regional method to estimate baseflow contribution to design flood events has been developed that is applicable for unregulated catchments across Australia. This method was developed using catchments across Australia with catchment areas between 7 and 7800 km2, and as such the approach is considered most suitable for application for catchments within this range. Practitioners should be mindful of these constraints when applying and interpreting the outcomes from this method.
Three concepts have been established to estimate baseflow from surface runoff characteristics:

listitem.para: Baseflow Peak Factor. This factor is applied to the estimated surface runoff peak flow to give the value of peak baseflow for an ARI of 10 years.
Baseflow Volume Factor. This factor is applied to the estimated surface runoff volume to give the volume of the baseflow for an ARI of 10 years.

Baseflow Under Peak Factor. This factor is applied to the estimated surface runoff peak flow to give the baseflow at the time of the peak surface runoff. This factor can be determined from the Baseflow Peak Factor, such that the Baseflow Under Peak Factor = 0.7 x Baseflow Peak Factor.

section.para: The Baseflow Peak Factor and Baseflow Volume Factor are presented in Figure 5 and Figure 6, which cover the whole of Australia. It should be noted that the maps represent the values for the total area upstream of the main stem of the river rather than any smaller sub-catchments.

ARR Project 7 developed a series of regression relationships to estimate the Baseflow Peak Factor and Baseflow Peak Volume based on catchment characteristics (SKM 2010). These are presented in Figure 5 and Figure 6 (and supporting spatial data for use with ArcGIS), and can be used to determine the Baseflow Peak Factor and the Baseflow Volume Factor for the 10 year ARI event for the catchment of interest.

These factors provide information on the baseflow contribution to design flood events for 10 year ARI event magnitudes. section.title: Generating the total streamflow hydrograph
section.para: The characteristics of the surface runoff, baseflow and total streamflow can be used to estimate the hydrograph for the event. For simplicity, a linear approach can typically be used to estimate the baseflow at each time step, by fitting between the data values estimated through the process described above and matching the baseflow volume. This time series can be manually added to the surface runoff time series data to generate a time series for the total streamflow. The time series generated through this process should be reviewed, and may require smoothing to produce a more realistic temporal distribution of baseflow. This process is presented in Figure 7.

figure.title: Total streamflow hydrograph generation approach, where (a) the data values calculated through the baseflow estimation process are plotted; (b) linear interpolation between the baseflow data points and matching the area under the curve to the baseflow event volume is used to estimate the baseflow time series, which is plotted on the hydrograph in green; and (c) the total streamflow time series is generated by summing the surface runoff and baseflow time series values, with the streamflow hydrograph plotted in red.

section.para: The process described in Section 3 is worked through in a number of different case study examples.

section.title: North Maroochy River at Eumundi, Queensland
section.para: Streamflow gauge 141009 is located on the North Maroochy River at Eumundi. Hourly flow data has been collected at this location since 1982, providing approximately 30 years of data. Very little data is missing or poor quality during this period. The catchment area is 40 km2.

The 10 year ARI event is of interest for this case study. The reviewed flow data was used to identify flood peaks, in particular the 10 year event. A comparable event was identified in the record in February 1999. The event hydrograph was plotted and key characteristics of the baseflow were identified manually (Figure 8; manually identified basaeflow features shown by black points). Straight lines were used to join the key baseflow features, to estimate the baseflow time series. In this instance, the baseflow peak occurs 18 hours after the peak of the streamflow

para.emphasis: Appendix A Calculation of the timing of the baseflow peak

section.para: Analyses undertaken to develop most of the method outlined in Section 4.2 is described in detail in separate technical documents, available online at the ARR update website (SKM, 2010, available online http://www.arr.org.au/p7.html). However, the background behind the calculation of the timing of the baseflow peak is not captured in those documents. A full description of the development of Equation 2 is provided below. The description below assumes that the reader has an understanding of the work presented in the separate technical documents, and a full background of the broader study concepts is not provided here.

More than 230 suitable catchments across Australia were identified for analysis for ARR Update Project 7, and hourly streamflow data was collated for each of these locations. A baseflow time series was generated from each flow record using the Lyne and Hollick digital filter, modified to suit hourly streamflow data. The top 4N flood events were identified in the hourly time series data for each catchment, generating a data set of more than 30,000 flood events across the 236 catchments. For each of these events, the magnitude and timing of the total streamflow peak and baseflow peak were identified. The time to these peaks was calculated from the start of the event. At each location, the average time to the streamflow and baseflow peaks were then calculated based on the 4N events.

For the purposes of this assessment, it was assumed that the total streamflow and surface runoff peaks would coincide. This is considered a reasonable assumption since surface runoff is generally the main component of the total streamflow hydrograph.

Analysis of the average time to peak data identified a strong relationship between the time to the surface runoff (and streamflow) and baseflow peaks, as presented in Figure 13. This relationship provides a direct calculation from which to estimate the timing of the baseflow peak, based upon knowledge of the surface runoff event generated using a flood event model.
